canonical_explanation.text: Some liquids conduct electricity while others do not. Liquids that conduct electricity are called conducting solutions (e.g., salt water, lemon juice, acid solutions). Distilled water is a poor conductor, but adding salt or acid makes it a good conductor. When electric current passes through a conducting liquid, it can cause chemical changes — this is called the chemical effect of electric current. These effects include deposition of metal on electrodes, production of gas bubbles, and change in colour of the solution. Electroplating is a practical application where a thin layer of a desired metal is coated onto another object using electric current. LED testers can be used to detect even weak currents flowing through liquids.
rules: Good conductors of electricity: metals, salt water, acid solutions.
Poor conductors (insulators): distilled water, rubber, wood, plastic.
Liquids that conduct electricity are called conducting solutions or electrolytes.
Chemical effects of current: metal deposition, gas bubbles, colour change of solution.
Electroplating: depositing a thin layer of a metal on another material using electric current.
In electroplating, the object to be plated is made the negative electrode (cathode).
The metal to be coated is made the positive electrode (anode) or dissolved in the solution.
Applications of electroplating: chromium plating, tin cans, gold/silver jewellery coating.
LED testers can detect weak currents that may not be detected by a bulb tester.
Adding impurities to distilled water makes it a conductor.

questions.question_text: Which of the following liquids is a good conductor of electricity?
questions.explanation_correct: Salt water is a good conductor of electricity because the dissolved salt dissociates into ions (sodium and chloride) that carry electric charge through the solution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Distilled water (A) is a poor conductor. Cooking oil (C) and kerosene (D) do not conduct electricity. Salt water (B) conducts well because of the dissolved ions.

questions.question_text: Distilled water does not conduct electricity because it:

options.text: Does not contain dissolved salts or ions

questions.explanation_correct: Distilled water does not conduct electricity because it is pure and does not contain dissolved salts or other impurities that would provide ions to carry electric current.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Temperature (A, C) is not the reason. Distilled water does not contain minerals (D) — that's the point. It lacks dissolved salts or ions (B) needed to conduct electricity.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a poor conductor of electricity?
questions.explanation_correct: Distilled water is a poor conductor of electricity because it does not have dissolved salts or impurities to provide ions for conducting current.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Copper wire (A) is an excellent conductor. Lemon juice (B) and vinegar (D) contain acids that dissociate into ions, making them conductors. Distilled water (C) lacks ions and is a poor conductor.

questions.question_text: When salt is added to distilled water, it starts conducting electricity because:

options.text: Salt dissolves and produces ions that carry electric charge
Salt changes the colour of water
Salt increases the temperature of water

questions.explanation_correct: When salt (NaCl) dissolves in water, it dissociates into sodium (Na+) and chloride (Cl-) ions. These ions are free to move and carry electric charge, making the solution a conductor.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Making water heavier (A), changing colour (C), or increasing temperature (D) are not reasons for conductivity. Salt produces ions (B) when dissolved, which carry electric charge through the solution.

questions.question_text: The chemical effects of electric current include:

options.text: Deposition of metal, gas bubbles, and colour change

questions.explanation_correct: When electric current passes through a conducting solution, it can cause chemical effects: deposition of metal on the electrodes, production of gas bubbles, and change in colour of the solution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Light (A), magnetism (C), and heating (D) are other effects of current but not chemical effects. Chemical effects specifically include metal deposition, gas production, and colour change (B).

questions.question_text: When electric current is passed through acidified water, the chemical effect observed is:

options.text: Gas bubbles are produced at the electrodes

questions.explanation_correct: When electric current passes through acidified water, water decomposes into hydrogen and oxygen gases. Bubbles of these gases are seen at the electrodes — this is electrolysis of water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water does not freeze (A), change colour (B), or evaporate (D) due to the current. The chemical effect is the production of gas bubbles (C) — hydrogen at the cathode and oxygen at the anode.

questions.question_text: When electric current passes through a solution of copper sulphate, a reddish-brown deposit appears on the negative electrode. This deposit is:
questions.explanation_correct: The reddish-brown deposit is copper. When current passes through copper sulphate solution, copper ions in the solution gain electrons at the negative electrode (cathode) and deposit as metallic copper.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Iron (A) is grey, gold (C) is golden-yellow, and silver (D) is silvery-white. The reddish-brown deposit from copper sulphate solution is copper (B) metal.

questions.question_text: Electroplating is a process of:

options.text: Coating a thin layer of a desired metal on another material using electric current

questions.explanation_correct: Electroplating is the process of depositing a thin layer of a desired metal (such as chromium, gold, or silver) onto another material using electric current passed through a conducting solution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electroplating is not about heating (A), mixing metals (C), or painting (D). It uses electric current (B) to deposit a thin metal coating on an object.

questions.question_text: In electroplating, the object to be plated is connected as the:
questions.explanation_correct: In electroplating, the object to be plated is connected as the negative electrode (cathode). Metal ions from the solution are attracted to the cathode and deposit on it as a thin metal layer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The object is not the anode (A) — the anode is made of the coating metal. It is not the battery (C) or switch (D). The object to be plated is the cathode (B), where metal deposition occurs.

questions.question_text: Why are bathroom taps and car bumpers coated with chromium?

options.text: Chromium plating makes them shiny and protects from corrosion
Chromium makes them conduct electricity better

questions.explanation_correct: Chromium plating provides a shiny, attractive appearance and protects the underlying metal from corrosion and rusting. Chromium does not corrode easily and gives a lustrous finish.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chromium is not necessarily cheaper (A) or lighter (C). Conductivity (D) is not the reason. Chromium plating (B) provides both shine and corrosion resistance.

questions.question_text: All liquids conduct electricity.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Not all liquids conduct electricity. Distilled water, cooking oil, and kerosene are examples of liquids that do not conduct electricity. Only liquids containing ions conduct electricity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Many liquids like distilled water, oil, and kerosene are poor conductors. Only liquids with dissolved ions (like salt water, acid solutions) conduct electricity.

questions.question_text: Passing electric current through a conducting solution can cause a chemical change.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. When electric current passes through a conducting solution, it can cause chemical changes such as deposition of metal on electrodes, production of gas bubbles, and change in colour of the solution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Chemical effects of electric current include metal deposition, gas formation, and colour changes in the solution.

questions.question_text: In electroplating, the metal to be coated is used as the negative electrode (cathode).
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. In electroplating, the metal to be coated (the plating metal) is used as the positive electrode (anode), not the cathode. The object to be plated is the cathode.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. The plating metal goes on the anode (positive electrode), where it dissolves into the solution. The object to be plated is the cathode (negative electrode), where metal deposits.

questions.question_text: Liquids that allow electric current to pass through them are called ___ solutions.
questions.explanation_correct: Conducting solutions are liquids that allow electric current to pass through them. They contain ions that are free to move and carry electric charge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'conducting'. Solutions with dissolved ions that can carry electric charge are called conducting solutions.

questions.question_text: The process of depositing a layer of a desired metal on another material using electric current is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Electroplating uses electric current to deposit a thin layer of a desired metal onto another material. It is widely used for decoration and corrosion protection.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'electroplating'. This process uses electrolysis to coat objects with a thin metallic layer.

questions.question_text: ___ water is a poor conductor of electricity because it lacks dissolved ions.
questions.explanation_correct: Distilled water is a poor conductor because it has been purified and does not contain dissolved salts or impurities that would provide ions to carry electric current.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Distilled'. Distilled water has been purified by evaporation and condensation, removing all dissolved salts and ions.

questions.question_text: An LED tester is preferred over a bulb tester for testing electrical conductivity of liquids because:

options.text: LEDs can detect even very weak currents that may not light up a bulb

questions.explanation_correct: LED testers can detect even very weak electric currents that may not be strong enough to light up an ordinary bulb. This makes LEDs more sensitive for testing the conductivity of liquids.
questions.explanation_incorrect: LEDs are actually smaller (A). They produce less heat (C). Cost (D) is not the main reason. LEDs are preferred because they glow even with very small currents (B), making them better detectors.

questions.question_text: Which of the following will make a tester's bulb glow?
questions.explanation_correct: Vinegar is an acidic solution containing acetic acid, which dissociates into ions in water. These ions conduct electric current, making the bulb glow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Kerosene (A) does not conduct electricity. Sugar solution (B) does not have ions. Distilled water (D) lacks dissolved ions. Vinegar (C) contains acetic acid that provides ions for conduction.

questions.question_text: When electric current is passed through a potato connected in a circuit, a greenish-blue spot appears near the positive electrode. This is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: The greenish-blue spot is a chemical change caused by the passage of electric current through the potato. This colour change is a chemical effect of electric current.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is not a heating (A), magnetic (B), or lighting (D) effect. The colour change in the potato is a chemical effect (C) caused by chemical reactions triggered by electric current.

questions.question_text: Tin cans used for storing food are made by electroplating iron with tin because:

options.text: Tin is a cheaper metal than iron
Tin is less reactive and prevents food contamination

questions.explanation_correct: Iron cans are coated with tin because tin is less reactive than iron and does not react with food acids or moisture. This prevents corrosion and food contamination, keeping the food safe.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tin is not cheaper than iron (A). Making cans heavier (C) is not desirable. Heat conduction (D) is not the main reason. Tin plating (B) protects food from contamination because tin is non-reactive with food.

questions.question_text: To electroplate a spoon with silver, the spoon should be made the ___ and a silver plate should be the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The spoon (object to be plated) is the cathode (negative electrode) where silver deposits. The silver plate is the anode (positive electrode) that dissolves into the solution to provide silver ions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The object to be plated must be the cathode, and the plating metal must be the anode. So the spoon is cathode and silver is anode (B). Reversing them (A) would plate the silver with spoon material.

questions.question_text: Tap water conducts electricity but distilled water does not. This is because tap water contains:

options.text: Dissolved minerals and salts that provide ions

questions.explanation_correct: Tap water contains dissolved minerals, salts, and impurities that dissociate into ions. These ions allow the flow of electric current, making tap water a conductor.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Oxygen content (A), hydrogen content (C), and temperature (D) are not the key factors. The dissolved minerals and salts (B) in tap water provide ions that conduct electricity.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a chemical effect of electric current?

options.text: Deposition of metal on an electrode
Change in colour of a solution

questions.explanation_correct: A filament bulb glowing is a heating effect (and lighting effect) of electric current, not a chemical effect. Chemical effects include metal deposition, gas production, and colour change.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Metal deposition (A), gas bubbles (B), and colour change (D) are all chemical effects. A bulb glowing (C) is a heating/lighting effect of current, not a chemical effect.

questions.question_text: During electroplating of a copper key with nickel, the electrolyte solution should contain:
questions.explanation_correct: To plate with nickel, the solution must contain nickel ions. Nickel sulphate solution provides these nickel ions, which deposit on the cathode (copper key) when current passes through.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Copper sulphate (A) would deposit copper, not nickel. Salt solution (C) would not deposit nickel. Sugar solution (D) doesn't conduct. Nickel sulphate (B) provides the nickel ions needed for plating.

questions.question_text: Why should we not test the conductivity of a liquid by connecting it directly to the mains?

options.text: Mains electricity is dangerous and can cause severe electric shock

questions.explanation_correct: Mains electricity in India is 220V AC, which is extremely dangerous and can cause severe electric shock, burns, or even death. Conductivity tests should only be done using low-voltage batteries.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The liquid will not evaporate (A) or freeze (C). The bulb might glow (D). The real danger is that mains electricity (B) is high voltage and can cause fatal electric shocks.

questions.question_text: Electroplating is used only for decoration purposes.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Electroplating is used for both decoration and protection. It protects metals from corrosion and rust, and in the case of tin-plated food cans, it prevents food contamination.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electroplating serves multiple purposes: decoration (gold/silver plating), corrosion protection (chromium plating), and food safety (tin plating on cans). It is not used only for decoration.

questions.question_text: Lemon juice is a poor conductor of electricity.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Lemon juice is a good conductor of electricity because it contains citric acid, which dissociates into ions in water. These ions can carry electric current.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lemon juice contains citric acid that provides ions when dissolved. These ions conduct electricity, making lemon juice a good conductor, not a poor one.

questions.question_text: When electric current is passed through copper sulphate solution, copper gets deposited on the ___ electrode.
questions.explanation_correct: Copper gets deposited on the negative electrode (cathode). Positive copper ions in the solution are attracted to the negatively charged cathode, where they gain electrons and deposit as metallic copper.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'negative'. Metal ions (positively charged) are attracted to the negative electrode (cathode), where they deposit as solid metal.

questions.question_text: In electroplating, the object to be plated acts as the ___ (cathode/anode).
questions.explanation_correct: The object to be plated is connected as the cathode (negative electrode). Metal ions from the solution deposit on the cathode, forming a thin metallic coating.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'cathode'. The cathode is the negative electrode where metal ions deposit, coating the object.

questions.question_text: A student passes current through a solution and observes bubbles at both electrodes. This indicates:

options.text: Chemical decomposition of the solution is producing gases

questions.explanation_correct: Bubbles at both electrodes indicate that the electric current is causing chemical decomposition of the solution, producing gases. For example, water decomposes into hydrogen and oxygen gases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The solution is not boiling (A). The electrodes are not dissolving (C). The battery running out (D) would reduce current. The bubbles indicate chemical decomposition (B) producing gases.

questions.question_text: Jewellery makers coat cheap metal jewellery with gold or silver using electroplating. Which of the following is the correct setup?

options.text: Jewellery as anode, gold as cathode, salt solution
Jewellery as cathode, gold as anode, gold salt solution
Both jewellery and gold as cathode, water
Jewellery as cathode, gold as anode, distilled water

questions.explanation_correct: The jewellery (to be plated) is the cathode. Gold (plating metal) is the anode. The solution must be a gold salt solution that contains gold ions to deposit on the jewellery.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the electrodes. Option C wrongly places both as cathode. Option D uses distilled water which won't work. The correct setup (B) has jewellery as cathode, gold as anode, and a gold salt solution.

questions.question_text: Which of the following solutions will conduct electricity the most?
questions.explanation_correct: Concentrated salt solution conducts electricity the most because it has the highest concentration of dissolved ions (Na+ and Cl-) that can carry electric charge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Distilled water (A) has no ions. Sugar solution (B) does not produce ions. Cooking oil (D) is a non-conductor. Concentrated salt solution (C) has the most ions and conducts the best.

questions.question_text: An LED in a tester glows when current passes through it. What does LED stand for?
questions.explanation_correct: LED stands for Light Emitting Diode. It is a semiconductor device that emits light when electric current passes through it. LEDs require very little current to glow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct full form is Light Emitting Diode (B). It is not Low Energy Device (A), Light Energy Detector (C), or Low Emission Device (D).

questions.question_text: During electrolysis of water, the volume of gas collected at the cathode is twice the volume at the anode because:

options.text: Water (H₂O) has two hydrogen atoms for every oxygen atom

questions.explanation_correct: Water (H₂O) contains two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom. During electrolysis, hydrogen is released at the cathode and oxygen at the anode. Since there are twice as many hydrogen atoms, twice the volume of hydrogen is collected.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Oxygen being heavier (A) doesn't explain the volume ratio. Cathode size (C) is not relevant. Hydrogen solubility (D) is not the primary reason. The 2:1 ratio comes from the formula H₂O (B) — two H atoms to one O atom.

questions.question_text: Iron bridges and automobile parts are often coated with zinc. This process is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Coating iron with a layer of zinc is called galvanisation. It protects iron from rusting because zinc is more reactive and forms a protective layer that corrodes instead of the iron underneath.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is not just painting (A), gold plating (C), or welding (D). Coating iron with zinc (B) is specifically called galvanisation, and it's a common method of corrosion protection.

questions.question_text: A student wants to test if honey conducts electricity. She dips the electrodes of a tester in honey, but the bulb does not glow. However, when she uses an LED tester, the LED glows faintly. This suggests that:

options.text: Honey is a weak conductor that allows a small current

questions.explanation_correct: Since the LED glowed faintly but the bulb didn't, honey allows a very small current to flow. This means honey is a weak (poor) conductor — it allows some current but not enough to light a bulb.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Honey is not a perfect conductor (A) — the bulb didn't glow. It's not a perfect insulator (B) — the LED did glow. The bulb was not necessarily broken (D). Honey is a weak conductor (C) that permits only a small current.

questions.question_text: When current passes through a solution of copper sulphate (blue colour), and the colour gradually fades, this is because:

options.text: Copper ions deposit on the electrode, reducing their concentration

questions.explanation_correct: The blue colour of copper sulphate is due to copper ions. As current flows, copper ions deposit as metallic copper on the cathode, reducing the number of copper ions in solution and causing the blue colour to fade.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Evaporation (A) and heating (C) don't explain the colour change. The battery running out (D) would stop the process. The colour fades because copper ions deposit on the electrode (B), reducing their concentration.

questions.question_text: An LED tester can detect weaker currents than a bulb tester.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. LEDs require very little current to glow, so they can detect even weak currents that may not be enough to light up a filament bulb. This makes LED testers more sensitive.
questions.explanation_incorrect: LEDs glow with very small currents. A filament bulb needs more current. So an LED tester is indeed more sensitive than a bulb tester.

questions.question_text: The chemical effects of electric current can be used to purify metals.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Electrolytic refining uses the chemical effects of electric current to purify metals. Impure metal is used as the anode, and pure metal deposits on the cathode from the solution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Electrolytic refining is a process where impure metal is dissolved at the anode and pure metal is deposited at the cathode using electric current.

questions.question_text: The process of using electric current to decompose a chemical compound is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Electrolysis is the process of using electric current to decompose a chemical compound into its elements or simpler substances. For example, water can be decomposed into hydrogen and oxygen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'electrolysis'. This process breaks down compounds using electric current, such as decomposing water into hydrogen and oxygen.

questions.question_text: Coating iron with a layer of zinc to prevent rusting is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Galvanisation is the process of coating iron or steel with zinc to protect it from rusting. The zinc layer acts as a barrier and also corrodes preferentially, protecting the iron underneath.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'galvanisation'. This is a common method of protecting iron from corrosion by coating it with zinc.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an advantage of electroplating?

options.text: It protects metals from corrosion and improves appearance
It increases the cost of production without any benefit

questions.explanation_correct: Electroplating provides a protective coating that prevents corrosion and rust, and it also improves the appearance of objects by giving them a shiny, attractive finish.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electroplating adds a very thin layer, not making objects significantly heavier (A). It does not weaken metals (C). It has clear benefits (D). Its main advantages are corrosion protection and improved appearance (B).

questions.question_text: Which of the following pairs contains a conductor and an insulator?
questions.explanation_correct: Salt water is a conductor (has dissolved ions) and distilled water is a poor conductor/insulator (lacks ions). This pair correctly has one conductor and one insulator.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Salt water and vinegar (A) are both conductors. Lemon juice and salt water (B) are both conductors. Distilled water and kerosene (D) are both insulators. Only option C has one conductor (salt water) and one insulator (distilled water).

questions.question_text: A student builds a simple circuit with a battery, LED, and two wires. When the free ends are dipped in a liquid, the LED glows. The liquid is most likely:
questions.explanation_correct: Dilute hydrochloric acid contains hydrogen and chloride ions that conduct electricity. The LED glows because current flows through the acidic solution. Oil, distilled water, and kerosene do not conduct.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cooking oil (A), distilled water (B), and kerosene (D) are poor conductors and would not make the LED glow. Dilute HCl (C) contains ions and conducts electricity.

questions.question_text: Which of the following changes can be observed when electric current is passed through a conducting solution for a long time?

options.text: The solution turns into a solid
Metal may deposit on electrodes, gas may be released, and solution colour may change
The electrodes become larger in size
The solution becomes a better insulator

questions.explanation_correct: When current passes through a conducting solution, chemical effects include metal deposition on electrodes, gas release (bubbles), and colour change of the solution. These are the observable chemical effects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The solution doesn't turn solid (A). The anode may dissolve, not grow (C). The solution doesn't become an insulator (D). The chemical effects include deposition, gas release, and colour change (B).

questions.question_text: Why is chromium preferred over other metals for electroplating?

options.text: Chromium is the cheapest metal available
Chromium is shiny, hard, and resistant to corrosion

questions.explanation_correct: Chromium is preferred for electroplating because it has a bright, shiny appearance, is very hard, and is highly resistant to corrosion. These properties make it ideal for coating bathroom fixtures and car parts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chromium is not the cheapest (A) or softest (C) metal, and it doesn't dissolve easily in water (D). It is chosen because it is shiny, hard, and corrosion-resistant (B).

questions.question_text: Adding more salt to water increases its ability to conduct electricity.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Adding more salt increases the concentration of ions in the solution. More ions mean more charge carriers, which increases the solution's ability to conduct electricity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. More dissolved salt means more ions (Na+ and Cl-) available to carry current, improving the solution's conductivity.

questions.question_text: In a conductivity tester using an LED, the LED glows brightly with one solution and dimly with another. What can be concluded?

options.text: The second solution is a better conductor
The first solution has more ions and is a better conductor

questions.explanation_correct: A brighter LED indicates more current flowing, which means the first solution has more ions and is a better conductor. The second solution allows less current, indicating fewer ions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The second solution is a poorer conductor (A is wrong). They are not equally conductive (C). The LED is not faulty (D). The first solution with brighter glow has more ions and conducts better (B).

questions.question_text: Electric current flows through a solution only if it contains free ___ to carry the charge.
questions.explanation_correct: Electric current in a solution is carried by free ions (charged atoms or groups of atoms). These ions move toward oppositely charged electrodes, creating a flow of charge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'ions'. In solutions, electric current is carried by ions (not electrons as in metals). These ions are produced when salts, acids, or bases dissolve.

questions.question_text: A manufacturer wants to make rust-proof iron nails. Which electroplating method would be most suitable?
questions.explanation_correct: Coating iron nails with zinc (galvanisation) is the most suitable method for rust prevention. Zinc is more reactive than iron and forms a protective layer, and it is much cheaper than gold or copper for this purpose.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Copper (A) is less reactive than iron and won't protect as well. Gold (C) would work but is extremely expensive. Aluminium paint (D) is not electroplating. Zinc coating (B) is effective and economical for rust prevention.
